image.altText: A worker inspects steel products at the Whyalla steelworks.

props.synopsis: The former owner of the Whyalla steelworks, Sanjeev Gupta's OneSteel Manufacturing, owed $18.5 million in royalties when it was forced into administration last year, the ABC can reveal.

title.children: Former Whyalla steelworks' owner's royalties debt revealed

image.altText: Four members of Britpop era band Pulp sit in a studio among instruments and recording equipment

props.synopsis: Pulp had been among the acts prepared to boycott the festival over the cancellation of a slot with the Palestinian-Australian author at Adelaide Writers' Week.

title.children: Pulp agree to Adelaide Festival show after apology to Randa Abdel-Fattah

image.altText: A clocktower rises from a historic-looking building in a city.

props.synopsis: Adelaide City Council will consider supporting an alternative literary festival following the cancellation of the 2026 Adelaide Writers' Week.

title.children: 'Guerilla' Adelaide writers' festival could get council support

image.altText: A water damaged road with waves coming under a fence and lapping against it.

props.synopsis: As erosion threatens roads and even homes in Robe in South Australia, artificial reefs and other options are on the table to fight back.

title.children: Tourist town considers artificial reef to stop popular beaches vanishing

image.altText: A woman standing beneath a jetty.

props.synopsis: South Australian ecologist Dr Faith Coleman has resigned from two state government algal bloom panels and criticised the state government's approach.

title.children: SA ecologist resigns from algal bloom panels, citing government's 'adversarial' approach

image.altText: A woman wearing a necklace and smile to camera

props.synopsis: The Adelaide Festival Corporation, which oversees Adelaide Writers' Week, has apologised to Palestinian Australian author Randa Abdel-Fattah and says she will be invited to speak at its next event in 2027.

title.children: Adelaide Festival Corporation apologises to author Randa Abdel-Fattah

image.altText: Laura Stein has short dark hair and is smiling

props.synopsis: Supreme Court Justice Laura Stein has been announced as South Australia's new Chief Justice — the first woman to be appointed to the role.

title.children: SA announces first female Chief Justice Laura Stein

image.altText: A woman wearing an Akubra hat crouches down and holds a sheep's head in her hands

props.synopsis: More than 250,000 people do not have ready access to a vet in Australia, and according to the industry, it is not completely down to a shortage. It is also a distribution issue, which is putting biosecurity at risk.

title.children: In vet care deserts, an hour can be the difference between life and death

image.altText: A large and unique looking purple and green flower

props.synopsis: A corpse flower at the Adelaide Botanic Garden is generating excitement but it is actually among five of the rare plant to bloom in the city this summer.

title.children: 'Smellanie' the corpse flower set to attract thousands to Adelaide Botanic Garden

image.altText: Pelicans perch on a wooden structure near a body of water

props.synopsis: Environmental protections along a huge stretch of the River Murray will be boosted, following a decision to officially list the area as "critically endangered", the federal government says.

title.children: Major new developments will need to be assessed on River Murray

image.altText: The smoke stacks of the Bayswater power station.

props.synopsis: In a move labelled a sign of the times, energy firm AGL was last week offering customers money to cut use during a heatwave.

title.children: Households 'paid to switch off' as extreme weather stalks power grid

image.altText: People stand around a bonfire at a protest in Tehran, Iran

props.synopsis: The White House says it will hold off on military action in Iran after the regime halted executions, but "all options remain on the table" if the killing of protesters continues.

title.children: 'No hanging today' in Iran, as US holds back from military action

image.altText: A woman holds a candle that illuminates her t-shirt, which reads Liberen A Todos Los Presos Politicos.

props.synopsis: Venezuela's new leader says political prisoners are being freed, but hundreds remain jailed, with families clinging to hope that America's intervention and ongoing pressure will eventually secure their loved ones' release

title.children: Zaida's son was snatched in the night and she's begging for his release

image.altText: A smiling older man and woman sit on some rocks near a waterway.

props.synopsis: Struggling to find answers about what happened in the week leading up to her death in hospital, Sue Smith's loved ones say they want hospitals to put more resources into investigating these types of incidents.

title.children: Family questions hospital care after woman dies from bloodstream infection

image.altText: A woman's hand holds a phone displaying a number of widgets for various apps.

props.synopsis: More than 4.7 million Australian social media accounts have been deactivated since laws banning children aged under 16 took effect in December, according to data released by the government.

title.children: Millions of accounts culled days after social media ban started, data shows

image.altText: An old newspaper clipping photo of two men and two women raising drinks.

props.synopsis: With whisky and lollies for sustenance and pigeons their only means of communication, Steve Harris and Doug Fleming crossed Bass Strait in a 4.5m dinghy in 1974.

title.children: Two blokes, whisky and lollies on a 'foolhardy' Bass Strait crossing

image.altText: Alexis Hutcheon sits on a stair well.

props.synopsis: A major Australian study finds standard antidepressants are not effective for around 20 per cent of people, who may need alternative treatments.

title.children: Antidepressants failing many people, major study reveals

image.altText: Anthony Albanese wears a suit and blue tie, and black-rimmed glasses. He stares intently just past the camera.

props.synopsis: Parliament will return early next week to debate new hate speech laws. But what exactly does the legislation include?

title.children: What is in the government's new hate speech laws?

image.altText: People in military fatigues disembark from a Royal Danish Air Force plane and board busses.

props.synopsis: As European countries send small numbers of troops to Greenland, the White House says their presence will not affect US President Donald Trump's ambitions for the island.

title.children: White House shrugs off presence of European troops in Greenland

image.altText: A close up image of Kevin Rudd with his hand on his chin.

props.synopsis: Test your knowledge of this week's news cycle here.

title.children: Weekly news quiz: An early departure and an Aussie Golden Globe win

image.altText: A python resting on a straw mat

props.synopsis: It's fair to say when a Brisbane resident woke up to discover a carpet python curled up on top of her she was rattled.

title.children: 'Babe, don't move': Woman wakes up to 2.5-metre python curled up on top of her

image.altText: A stone statue lies in several large pieces after being smashed on a brick and concrete floor.

props.synopsis: Residents of a north-west NSW town are angry and heartbroken after a statue with more than 100 years of history was unceremoniously shattered in the middle of the night.

title.children: Outrage after 'attack' on 100-year-old Anzac statue caught on CCTV

image.altText: woman holding cheque

props.synopsis: Australian woman Laura Wells was confused to find an "official-looking letter" from the US with a $51 reimbursement, but it turns out it was legitimate.

title.children: US lawsuit results in mystery cheque from Amazon in woman's mailbox

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

props.synopsis: The Australian dollar jumps again on potentially more dovish policy from the US Federal Reserve, while Taiwan and the US have struck a major semiconductor deal. Follow the day's events and insights as they happen with our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Aussie dollar nudges 67 US cents, Wall Street up on 'massive' AI chips deal

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Aussie dollar nears 67 US cents on rate expectations

image.altText: A metal pipe bomb post-detonation laying on leaf-littered ground.

props.synopsis: ACT police say they have found four more pipe bombs in the Belconnen area, after 11 explosive devices were discovered close to Lake Ginninderra over the previous two days.

title.children: Four more pipe bombs found in Canberra as probe continues

image.altText: A close of two men running

props.synopsis: An Albany man runs roughly three marathons in laps of a hilly parkrun to raise funds for a charity that helped him through a tough time.

title.children: Twenty-four parkruns in 24 hours no sweat for WA runner

image.altText: A close up of a woman's hand holding a cross necklace.

props.synopsis: Documents leaked to the ABC reveal an "apocalyptic Christian cult" is targeting Ballarat, Bendigo, Geelong and Darwin.

title.children: Ex-member says Shincheonji 'cult' spreading across the country

image.altText: Storm clouds roll in over Kununurra.

props.synopsis: A Kimberley pastoralist says the radar will be of little use by the time it comes back online at the end of the wet season.

title.children: WA farmers grapple with radar outage during wet season

image.altText: A dragonfly resting on a mobile phone with the Wikipedia page for dragonfly on the screen of phone

props.synopsis: Wikipedia is celebrating 25 years of the online encyclopedia and the enormous impact its had, while looking forward to its future. But some controversies from the past refuse to die.

title.children: Wikipedia is 25, but some old fights are still going

image.altText: Nikita Tszyu and Michael Zerafa face to face at the weigh-ins

props.synopsis: There is no love lost between Nikita Tszyu and Michael Zerafa as they meet for one final time before their much-anticipated fight in Brisbane.

title.children: Tszyu and Zerafa separated by security in fiery weigh-in clash

image.altText: a man in a blue shirt and cap poses with his black cattle under shade cloth

props.synopsis: Once seen as barren landscapes, feedlots across Australia have been reshaping their image. With industry encouraging its operators to install shade, uptake has been widespread.

title.children: Inside the push to shade 1.3 million feedlot animals

image.altText: Images of tar black spheres found washed up on the sand of Sydney eastern suburbs beaches.

props.synopsis: The NSW Environment Protection Authority identified the Malabar wastewater treatment system as the origin of the debris balls plaguing beaches in Sydney.

title.children: $3bn wastewater overhaul after debris balls on Sydney beaches

image.altText: Daniel Sanders in action at the Dakar Rally

props.synopsis: Daniel Sanders returns to complete the 11th stage of the Dakar Rally less than 24 hours after suffering a broken collarbone and sternum.

title.children: 'We don't quit': Aussie returns to Dakar Rally after broken collarbone

image.altText: Hands and feet are visible as an islander kneels among a swarm of tiny, baby red crabs.

props.synopsis: Wildlife officials on one of Australia's most remote territories are welcoming the final chapter of its famous red crab migration, the return to shore of millions of baby crabs.

title.children: 'A carpet of red' as millions of baby crabs storm Christmas Island's beaches
